item.title: Report E-2024040030
item.description:
Report E-2024040030

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-04T15:13:28+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-26
  • City: KENNESAW
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 3000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 26, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1219 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel deployed granular absorbents to the UN1219-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. The damaged 55-gallon drum was overpacked into one (1) 85-gallon drum. Both drums were staged onsite for future disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024040003
item.description:
Report E-2024040003

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-03T15:11:30+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-29
  • City: LAWRENCEVILLE
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NNC experienced a battery acid release from a 2500-pound UN2794 battery. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-gallons of battery acid released to a 4’ x 15’ area of the trailer floor and a 11’ x 54’ area of the concrete lot below due to a load shift. The battery was re-secured for shipment on. Sodium bicab and baking soda were deployed and worked into the impacted areas to clean and neutralize the release. All impacted absorbents and PPE were containerized into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.
